definition.name: Guild Artisan / Guild Merchant
definition.description:
You are a member of an artisan’s guild, skilled in a particular field and closely associated with other artisans. You are a well-established part of the mercantile world, freed by talent and wealth from the constraints of a feudal social order. You learned your skills as an apprentice to a master artisan, under the sponsorship of your guild, until you became a master in your own right.

Skill Proficiencies: Insight, Persuasion

Tool Proficiencies: One type of artisan’s tools

Languages: One of your choice

Equipment: A set of artisan’s tools (one of your choice), a letter of introduction from your guild, a set of traveler’s clothes, and a pouch containing 15 gp

Guild Business

Guilds are generally found in cities large enough to support several artisans practicing the same trade. However, your guild might instead be a loose network of artisans who each work in a different village within a larger realm. Work with your DM to determine the nature of your guild. You can select your guild business from the Guild Business table or roll randomly.

d20 Guild Business
1 Alchemists and apothecaries
2 Armorers, locksmiths, and finesmiths
3 Brewers, distillers, and vintners
4 Calligraphers, scribes, and scriveners
5 Carpenters, roofers, and plasterers
6 Cartographers, surveyors, and chart-makers
7 Cobblers and shoemakers
8 Cooks and bakers
9 Glassblowers and glaziers
10 Jewelers and gemcutters
11 Leatherworkers, skinners, and tanners
12 Masons and stonecutters
13 Painters, limners, and sign-makers
14 Potters and tile-makers
15 Shipwrights and sailmakers
16 Smiths and metal-forgers
17 Tinkers, pewterers, and casters
18 Wagon-makers and wheelwrights
19 Weavers and dyers
20 Woodcarvers, coopers, and bowyers

As a member of your guild, you know the skills needed to create finished items from raw materials (reflected in your proficiency with a certain kind of artisan’s tools), as well as the principles of trade and good business practices. The question now is whether you abandon your trade for adventure, or take on the extra effort to weave adventuring and trade together.

Feature: Guild Membership

As an established and respected member of a guild, you can rely on certain benefits that membership provides. Your fellow guild members will provide you with lodging and food if necessary, and pay for your funeral if needed. In some cities and towns, a guildhall offers a central place to meet other members of your profession, which can be a good place to meet potential patrons, allies, or hirelings.

Guilds often wield tremendous political power. If you are accused of a crime, your guild will support you if a good case can be made for your innocence or the crime is justifiable. You can also gain access to powerful political figures through the guild, if you are a member in good standing. Such connections might require the donation of money or magic items to the guild’s coffers.

You must pay dues of 5 gp per month to the guild. If you miss payments, you must make up back dues to remain in the guild’s good graces.

Variant Guild Artisan: Guild Merchant

Instead of an artisans’ guild, you might belong to a guild of traders, caravan masters, or shopkeepers. You don’t craft items yourself but earn a living by buying and selling the works of others (or the raw materials artisans need to practice their craft). Your guild might be a large merchant consortium (or family) with interests across the region. Perhaps you transported goods from one place to another, by ship, wagon, or caravan, or bought them from traveling traders and sold them in your own little shop. In some ways, the traveling merchant’s life lends itself to adventure far more than the life of an artisan.
definition.shortDescription: You are a member of an artisan’s guild, skilled in a particular field and closely associated with other artisans. You are a well-established part of the mercantile world, freed by talent and wealth from the constraints of a feudal social order. You learned your skills as an apprentice to a master artisan, under the sponsorship of your guild, until you became a master in your own right.
definition.equipmentDescription: A set of artisan’s tools (one of your choice), a letter of introduction from your guild, a set of traveler’s clothes, and a pouch containing 15 gp
definition.featureDescription:
As an established and respected member of a guild, you can rely on certain benefits that membership provides. Your fellow guild members will provide you with lodging and food if necessary, and pay for your funeral if needed. In some cities and towns, a guildhall offers a central place to meet other members of your profession, which can be a good place to meet potential patrons, allies, or hirelings.

Guilds often wield tremendous political power. If you are accused of a crime, your guild will support you if a good case can be made for your innocence or the crime is justifiable. You can also gain access to powerful political figures through the guild, if you are a member in good standing. Such connections might require the donation of money or magic items to the guild’s coffers.

You must pay dues of 5 gp per month to the guild. If you miss payments, you must make up back dues to remain in the guild’s good graces.
definition.suggestedCharacteristicsDescription: Guild artisans are among the most ordinary people in the world—until they set down their tools and take up an adventuring career. They understand the value of hard work and the importance of community, but they’re vulnerable to sins of greed and covetousness.

personalityTraits.description: I believe that anything worth doing is worth doing right. I can’t help it—I’m a perfectionist.
I’m a snob who looks down on those who can’t appreciate fine art.
I always want to know how things work and what makes people tick.
I’m full of witty aphorisms and have a proverb for every occasion.
I’m rude to people who lack my commitment to hard work and fair play.
I like to talk at length about my profession.
I don’t part with my money easily and will haggle tirelessly to get the best deal possible.
I’m well known for my work, and I want to make sure everyone appreciates it. I’m always taken aback when people haven’t heard of me.

ideals.description: Community. It is the duty of all people to strengthen the bonds and security of communities. (Lawful)
Generosity. My talents were given to me so that I could use them to benefit the world. (Good)
Freedom. Everyone should be free to pursue his or her own livelihood. (Chaotic)
Greed. I’m only in it for the money. (Evil)
People. I’m committed to the people I care about, not to ideals. (Neutral)
Aspiration. I work hard to be the best there is at my craft. (Any)

bonds.description: The workshop where I learned my trade is the most important place in the world to me.
I created a great work for someone, and then found them unworthy to receive it. I’m still looking for someone worthy.
I owe my guild a great debt for forging me into the person I am today.
I pursue wealth to secure someone’s love.
One day I will return to my guild and prove that I am the greatest artisan of them all.
I will get revenge on the evil forces that destroyed my place of business and ruined my livelihood.

flaws.description: I’ll do anything to get my hands on something rare or priceless.
I’m quick to assume that someone is trying to cheat me.
No one must ever learn that I once stole money from guild coffers.
I’m never satisfied with what I have—I always want more.
I would kill to acquire a noble title.
I’m horribly jealous of anyone who can outshine my handiwork. Everywhere I go, I’m surrounded by rivals.

race.description:
Elves are a magical people of otherworldly grace, living in the world but not entirely part of it.

Racial Traits
+2 Dexterity, Darkvision, Keen Senses, Fey Ancestry, Trance

As a wood elf, you have keen senses and intuition, and your fleet feet carry you quickly and stealthily through your native forests. This category includes the wild elves (grugach) of Greyhawk and the Kagonesti of Dragonlance, as well as the races called wood elves in Greyhawk and the Forgotten Realms. In Faerûn, wood elves (also called wild elves, green elves, or forest elves) are reclusive and distrusting of non-elves.

Wood elves’ skin tends to be copperish in hue, sometimes with traces of green. Their hair tends toward browns and blacks, but it is occasionally blond or copper-colored. Their eyes are green, brown, or hazel.

definition.name: Darkvision
definition.description: Accustomed to twilit forests and the night sky, you have superior vision in dark and dim conditions. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can’t discern color in darkness, only shades of gray.
definition.snippet: You can see in darkness (shades of gray) up to 60 ft.

definition.name: Keen Senses
definition.description: You have proficiency in the Perception skill.
definition.snippet: You have proficiency in the Perception skill.

definition.name: Fey Ancestry
definition.description: You have advantage on saving throws against being charmed, and magic can’t put you to sleep.
definition.snippet: You have advantage on saves against being charmed, and magic can’t put you to sleep.

definition.name: Trance
definition.description: Elves don’t need to sleep. Instead, they meditate deeply, remaining semiconscious, for 4 hours a day. (The Common word for such meditation is “trance.”) While meditating, you can dream after a fashion; such dreams are actually mental exercises that have become reflexive through years of practice. After resting in this way, you gain the same benefit that a human does from 8 hours of sleep.
definition.snippet: You don't need to sleep, but meditate semiconsciously for 4 hours a day. While meditating, you can dream after a fashion; such dreams are actually mental exercises that have become reflexive through years of practice. After resting in this way, you gain the same benefit that a human does from 8 hours of sleep.

definition.name: Ability Score Increase
definition.description: Your Dexterity score increases by 2.

definition.name: Languages
definition.description: You can speak, read, and write Common and Elvish. Elvish is fluid, with subtle intonations and intricate grammar. Elven literature is rich and varied, and their songs and poems are famous among other races. Many bards learn their language so they can add Elvish ballads to their repertoires.

definition.name: Age
definition.description: Although elves reach physical maturity at about the same age as humans, the elven understanding of adulthood goes beyond physical growth to encompass worldly experience. An elf typically claims adulthood and an adult name around the age of 100 and can live to be 750 years old.

definition.name: Size
definition.description: Elves range from under 5 to over 6 feet tall and have slender builds. Your size is Medium.

definition.name: Speed
definition.description: Your base walking speed is 30 feet.

definition.name: Elf Weapon Training
definition.description: You have proficiency with the longsword, shortsword, shortbow, and longbow.
definition.snippet: You have proficiency with the longsword, shortsword, shortbow, and longbow.

definition.name: Fleet of Foot
definition.description: Your base walking speed increases to 35 feet.
definition.snippet: Your base walking speed increases to 35 feet.

definition.name: Mask of the Wild
definition.description: You can attempt to hide even when you are only lightly obscured by foliage, heavy rain, falling snow, mist, and other natural phenomena.
definition.snippet: You can attempt to hide even when you are only lightly obscured.

definition.name: Ability Score Increase
definition.description: Your Wisdom score increases by 1.

notes.allies: A nomadic group of wood elves his family is from, the The Verdant Sojourners.
notes.organizations:
The guild to which Kaelen belongs is known as the "Cogs of Obscura."

The "Cogs of Obscura" is a clandestine association operating from the fringes of societal norms. Known primarily for its merchantile ventures, the guild specializes in the acquisition, refurbishment, and subsequent resale of arcane and mechanical artifacts. Members of the guild, often distinguished by their subtlety, wit, and deft skills, are renowned for their abilities to procure objects of interest from the most unlikely of places.

Operating under the guiding principle of "Profit in the Shadows", the Cogs of Obscura guild finds opportunities in the underbelly of society, trading in curiosities and oddities that straddle the line between the legal and the forbidden. As a place of refuge for the resourceful, cunning, and occasionally morally ambiguous, the guild has garnered a reputation as a haven for those with a penchant for the unconventional.

Despite their dubious undertakings, the Cogs of Obscura retain an undercurrent of honor amongst thieves. They maintain a strict code of conduct, an unspoken creed that prioritizes loyalty to the guild and its members above all else. This hidden camaraderie ensures their survival in a world that seldom understands or accepts them. And in the center of this world, one finds Kaelen - a merchant, a craftsman, and an undeciphered enigma.
notes.enemies: The nameless mind flayed Duergar dwarf who killed his elder brother and drove his family from his village.
notes.backstory:
Emerging from the silvan tapestry of his childhood, Kaelen, a son of the ancient Wood Elf lineage, was a consummate hunter who once wove his life into the primeval rhythms of the forest. But his idyllic existence was abruptly sundered when the nefarious Duergar, dread dwarves known for their cruelty and darkness, ravaged his ancestral home.

In one fateful skirmish, the oldest of the village defenders fell—his brother, the stalwart elder whom he had looked up to all his life. It was a horrific sight that pierced Kaelen's young heart, forever etching the image of the brutal dwarf executioner into his memory. The cold-hearted dwarf, after dealing the mortal blow, casually dropped a trinket—a puzzle box of exquisite workmanship and mysterious origins. Whether by fate or chance, Kaelen picked up the discarded artifact as he fled the remnants of his ruined home, a lasting memento of his brother's sacrifice. Despite years of relentless attempts, he was unable to unravel the enigmatic design of the trinket, his efforts thwarted at each turn.

Now, Kaelen makes his dwelling in the cozy, albeit inconspicuous, inn at La Cun'dar, a rustic hamlet nestled within the sweeping landscape of PrimTerra. To the casual observer, he is merely a humble merchant affiliated with a local guild. Yet, beneath this veneer of respectability, Kaelen has crafted a clandestine existence. He excels in the shadowy arts of thievery, purloining valuable artifacts only to deconstruct, augment, and sell them as unique mechanical marvels.

His workmanship, an amalgamation of pilfered technology and elven artistry, is without equal. Yet, even amidst his newfound life, the puzzle trinket—the one keepsake from his past—remains an unsolvable enigma, a symbol of his lost home, and a testament to the brother he could not save. As his deft fingers continue to ply their craft, Kaelen remains a wayfarer on the road of life, forever haunted by his past, yet relentless in his journey towards a home yet undiscovered.

traits.personalityTraits: I always want to know how things work and what makes people tick.
traits.flaws: I’ll do anything to get my hands on something rare or priceless.
traits.appearance:
Standing at a modest height, Kaelen is a figure of subtle charm and woodland grace. His lean, agile body is honed by a lifetime spent navigating the forest's challenging terrain and surviving its perilous encounters. Ashen brown hair cascades to his shoulders, occasionally tied back to prevent any hindrance during his dexterous activities.

Emerald-green eyes, a marking of his Wood Elf heritage, are sharp and inquisitive. They possess an alluring depth that bespeaks a soul who has witnessed beauty and terror in equal measure, their luminous glow flickering with fragments of untold stories.

The only constant in his appearance is the intricate puzzle trinket that dangles from his neck, an unopened relic of his past. It sways gently as he moves, a reminder of the loss he carries and the mystery he is yet to solve. Kaelen, in all his elfin elegance, is a living embodiment of the captivating secret life he leads.

definition.name: Leather
definition.description: The breastplate and shoulder protectors of this armor are made of leather that has been stiffened by being boiled in oil. The rest of the armor is made of softer and more flexible materials.

definition.name: Dagger
definition.description: Proficiency with a dagger allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

properties.name: Finesse
properties.description: When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

properties.name: Light
properties.description: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

properties.name: Thrown
properties.description: If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

definition.name: Dagger
definition.description: Proficiency with a dagger allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

properties.name: Finesse
properties.description: When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

properties.name: Light
properties.description: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

properties.name: Thrown
properties.description: If a weapon has the thrown property, you can throw the weapon to make a ranged attack. If the weapon is a melee weapon, you use the same ability modifier for that attack roll and damage roll that you would use for a melee attack with the weapon. For example, if you throw a handaxe, you use your Strength, but if you throw a dagger, you can use either your Strength or your Dexterity, since the dagger has the finesse property.

definition.name: Shortbow
definition.description: Proficiency with a shortbow allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

properties.name: Ammunition
properties.description:
You can use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack only if you have ammunition to fire from the weapon. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield. 
If you use a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a melee attack, you treat the weapon as an improvised weapon (see "Improvised Weapons" later in the section). A sling must be loaded to deal any damage when used in this way.

properties.name: Range
properties.description: A weapon that can be used to make a ranged attack has a range in parentheses after the ammunition or thrown property. The range lists two numbers. The first is the weapon's normal range in feet, and the second indicates the weapon's long range. When attacking a target beyond normal range, you have disadvantage on the attack roll. You can't attack a target beyond the weapon's long range.

properties.name: Two-Handed
properties.description: This weapon requires two hands when you attack with it.

definition.name: Shortsword
definition.description: Proficiency with a shortsword allows you to add your proficiency bonus to the attack roll for any attack you make with it.

properties.name: Finesse
properties.description: When making an attack with a finesse weapon, you use your choice of your Strength or Dexterity modifier for the attack and damage rolls. You must use the same modifier for both rolls.

properties.name: Light
properties.description: A light weapon is small and easy to handle, making it ideal for use when fighting with two weapons.

definition.name: Arrows
definition.description: Arrows are used with a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.

definition.name: Backpack
definition.description:
A backpack is a leather pack carried on the back, typically with straps to secure it. A backpack can hold 1 cubic foot/ 30 pounds of gear.

You can also strap items, such as a bedroll or a coil of rope, to the outside of a backpack.

definition.name: Poison, Basic (vial)
definition.description: You can use the poison in this vial to coat one slashing or piercing weapon or up to three pieces of ammunition. Applying the poison takes an action. A creature hit by the poisoned weapon or ammunition must succeed on a DC 10 Constitution saving throw or take 1d4 poison damage. Once applied, the poison retains potency for 1 minute before drying.

definition.name: Tinker's Tools
definition.description: These special tools include the items needed to pursue a craft or trade. Proficiency with a set of artisan's tools lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make using the tools in your craft. Each type of artisan's tools requires a separate proficiency.

definition.name: Poisoner's Kit
definition.description: A poisoner's kit includes the vials, chemicals, and other equipment necessary for the creation of poisons. Proficiency with this kit lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make to craft or use poisons.

definition.name: Thieves' Tools
definition.description: This set of tools includes a small file, a set of lock picks, a small mirror mounted on a metal handle, a set of narrow-bladed scissors, and a pair of pliers. Proficiency with these tools lets you add your proficiency bonus to any ability checks you make to disarm traps or open locks.

definition.name: Ball Bearings (bag of 1,000)
definition.description: As an action, you can spill these tiny metal balls from their pouch to cover a level, square area that is 10 feet on a side. A creature moving across the covered area must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw or fall prone. A creature moving through the area at half speed doesn't need to make the save.

definition.name: Bell
definition.description: A standard bell that rings, typically used for signaling.

definition.name: Candle
definition.description: For 1 hour, a candle sheds bright light in a 5-foot radius and dim light for an additional 5 feet.

definition.name: Crowbar
definition.description: Using a crowbar grants advantage to Strength checks where the crowbar's leverage can be applied.

definition.name: Hammer
definition.description: This one-handed hammer with an iron head is useful for pounding pitons into a wall.

definition.name: Lantern, Hooded
definition.description: A hooded lantern casts bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet. Once lit, it burns for 6 hours on a flask (1 pint) of oil. As an action, you can lower the hood, reducing the light to dim light in a 5-foot radius.

definition.name: Oil (flask)
definition.description: Oil usually comes in a clay flask that holds 1 pint. As an action, you can splash the oil in this flask onto a creature within 5 feet of you or throw it up to 20 feet, shattering it on impact. Make a ranged attack against a target creature or object, treating the oil as an improvised weapon. On a hit, the target is covered in oil. If the target takes any fire damage before the oil dries (after 1 minute), the target takes an additional 5 fire damage from the burning oil. You can also pour a flask of oil on the ground to cover a 5-foot-square area, provided that the surface is level. If lit, the oil burns for 2 rounds and deals 5 fire damage to any creature that enters the area or ends its turn in the area. A creature can take this damage only once per turn.

definition.name: Piton
definition.description: When a wall doesn’t offer handholds and footholds, you can make your own. A piton is a steel spike with an eye through which you can loop a rope.

definition.name: Rations (1 day)
definition.description: Rations consist of dry foods suitable for extended travel, including jerky, dried fruit, hardtack, and nuts.

definition.name: Rope, Hempen (50 feet)
definition.description: Rope, has 2 hit points and can be burst with a DC 17 Strength check.

definition.name: Tinderbox
definition.description: This small container holds flint, fire steel, and tinder (usually dry cloth soaked in light oil) used to kindle a fire. Using it to light a torch -- or anything else with abundant, exposed fuel -- takes an action. Lighting any other fire takes 1 minute.

definition.name: Waterskin
definition.description: A waterskin can hold 4 pints of liquid.

definition.name: String
definition.description: A 10-foot length of string, typically found in a burglar's pack.

definition.name: Rogue
definition.description:
A scoundrel who uses stealth and trickery to overcome obstacles and enemies

Hit Die: d8
Primary Ability: Dexterity
Saves: Dexterity & Intelligence
definition.equipmentDescription:
You start with the following equipment, in addition to the equipment granted by your background:

  • (a) a rapier or (b) a shortsword
  • (a) a shortbow and quiver of 20 arrows or (b) a shortsword
  • (a) a burglar’s pack, (b) a dungeoneer’s pack, or (c) an explorer’s pack
  • Leather armor, two daggers, and thieves’ tools

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 10th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 8th level, and again at 10th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 12th level, and again at 16th and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 16th level, and again at 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

classFeatures.name: Expertise
classFeatures.description:
At 1st level, choose two of your skill proficiencies, or one of your skill proficiencies and your proficiency with thieves’ tools. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.

At 6th level, you can choose two more of your proficiencies (in skills or with thieves’ tools) to gain this benefit.

classFeatures.name: Sneak Attack
classFeatures.description:
Beginning at 1st level, you know how to strike subtly and exploit a foe’s distraction. Once per turn, you can deal an extra 1d6 damage to one creature you hit with an attack if you have advantage on the attack roll. The attack must use a finesse or a ranged weapon.

You don’t need advantage on the attack roll if another enemy of the target is within 5 feet of it, that enemy isn’t incapacitated, and you don’t have disadvantage on the attack roll.

The amount of the extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Sneak Attack column of the Rogue table.

classFeatures.name: Thieves’ Cant
classFeatures.description:
During your rogue training you learned thieves’ cant, a secret mix of dialect, jargon, and code that allows you to hide messages in seemingly normal conversation. Only another creature that knows thieves’ cant understands such messages. It takes four times longer to convey such a message than it does to speak the same idea plainly.

In addition, you understand a set of secret signs and symbols used to convey short, simple messages, such as whether an area is dangerous or the territory of a thieves’ guild, whether loot is nearby, or whether the people in an area are easy marks or will provide a safe house for thieves on the run.

classFeatures.name: Cunning Action
classFeatures.description: Starting at 2nd level, your quick thinking and agility allow you to move and act quickly. You can take a bonus action on each of your turns in combat. This action can be used only to take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.

classFeatures.name: Roguish Archetype
classFeatures.description: At 3rd level, you choose an archetype that you emulate in the exercise of your rogue abilities: Thief, detailed at the end of the class description, or one from another source. Your archetype choice grants you features at 3rd level and then again at 9th, 13th, and 17th level.

classFeatures.name: Uncanny Dodge
classFeatures.description: Starting at 5th level, when an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to halve the attack’s damage against you.

classFeatures.name: Evasion
classFeatures.description: Beginning at 7th level, you can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain area effects, such as an ancient red dragon’s fiery breath or an ice storm spell. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

classFeatures.name: Reliable Talent
classFeatures.description: By 11th level, you have refined your chosen skills until they approach perfection. Whenever you make an ability check that lets you add your proficiency bonus, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

classFeatures.name: Blindsense
classFeatures.description: Starting at 14th level, if you are able to hear, you are aware of the location of any hidden or invisible creature within 10 feet of you.

classFeatures.name: Slippery Mind
classFeatures.description: By 15th level, you have acquired greater mental strength. You gain proficiency in Wisdom saving throws.

classFeatures.name: Elusive
classFeatures.description: Beginning at 18th level, you are so evasive that attackers rarely gain the upper hand against you. No attack roll has advantage against you while you aren’t incapacitated.

classFeatures.name: Stroke of Luck
classFeatures.description:
At 20th level, you have an uncanny knack for succeeding when you need to. If your attack misses a target within range, you can turn the miss into a hit. Alternatively, if you fail an ability check, you can treat the d20 roll as a 20.

Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a short or long rest.

classFeatures.name: Proficiencies
classFeatures.description:
Armor: Light armor
Weapons: Simple weapons, hand crossbows, longswords, rapiers, shortswords
Tools: Thieves’ tools
Saving Throws: Dexterity, Intelligence
Skills: Choose four from Acrobatics, Athletics, Deception, Insight, Intimidation, Investigation, Perception, Performance, Persuasion, Sleight of Hand, and Stealth

classFeatures.name: Expertise
classFeatures.description: At 6th level, choose two more of your skill proficiencies, or one more of your skill proficiencies and your proficiency with thieves’ tools. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.

classFeatures.name: Hit Points
classFeatures.description:
Hit Dice: 1d8 per rogue level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per rogue level after 1st

classFeatures.name: Ability Score Improvement
classFeatures.description:
When you reach 10th level, and again at 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 10th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 8th level, and again at 10th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 12th level, and again at 16th and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 16th level, and again at 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

definition.name: Expertise
definition.description:
At 1st level, choose two of your skill proficiencies, or one of your skill proficiencies and your proficiency with thieves’ tools. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.

At 6th level, you can choose two more of your proficiencies (in skills or with thieves’ tools) to gain this benefit.
definition.snippet: Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make for two chosen proficiencies. [6th] Choose two additional proficiencies.

definition.name: Sneak Attack
definition.description:
Beginning at 1st level, you know how to strike subtly and exploit a foe’s distraction. Once per turn, you can deal an extra 1d6 damage to one creature you hit with an attack if you have advantage on the attack roll. The attack must use a finesse or a ranged weapon.

You don’t need advantage on the attack roll if another enemy of the target is within 5 feet of it, that enemy isn’t incapacitated, and you don’t have disadvantage on the attack roll.

The amount of the extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Sneak Attack column of the Rogue table.
definition.snippet: Once per turn, you can deal an extra {{scalevalue}} damage to one creature you hit with an attack with a finesse or ranged weapon if you have advantage on the attack roll. You don’t need advantage on the attack roll if another enemy of the target is within 5 ft. of it, that enemy isn’t incapacitated, and you don’t have disadvantage on the attack roll.

definition.name: Thieves’ Cant
definition.description:
During your rogue training you learned thieves’ cant, a secret mix of dialect, jargon, and code that allows you to hide messages in seemingly normal conversation. Only another creature that knows thieves’ cant understands such messages. It takes four times longer to convey such a message than it does to speak the same idea plainly.

In addition, you understand a set of secret signs and symbols used to convey short, simple messages, such as whether an area is dangerous or the territory of a thieves’ guild, whether loot is nearby, or whether the people in an area are easy marks or will provide a safe house for thieves on the run.
definition.snippet: You have learned thieves’ cant, a secret mix of dialect, jargon, and code that allows you to hide messages in seemingly normal conversation. It takes four times longer to convey such a message than it does to speak the same idea plainly.

definition.name: Cunning Action
definition.description: Starting at 2nd level, your quick thinking and agility allow you to move and act quickly. You can take a bonus action on each of your turns in combat. This action can be used only to take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.
definition.snippet: You can take a bonus action on each of your turns to take the Dash, Disengage, or Hide action.

definition.name: Roguish Archetype
definition.description: At 3rd level, you choose an archetype that you emulate in the exercise of your rogue abilities: Thief, detailed at the end of the class description, or one from another source. Your archetype choice grants you features at 3rd level and then again at 9th, 13th, and 17th level.

definition.name: Uncanny Dodge
definition.description: Starting at 5th level, when an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to halve the attack’s damage against you.
definition.snippet: When an attacker that you can see hits you with an attack, you can use your reaction to halve the attack’s damage against you.

definition.name: Evasion
definition.description: Beginning at 7th level, you can nimbly dodge out of the way of certain area effects, such as an ancient red dragon’s fiery breath or an ice storm spell. When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.
definition.snippet: When you are subjected to an effect that allows you to make a DEX saving throw to take only half damage, you instead take no damage if you succeed on the saving throw, and only half damage if you fail.

definition.name: Reliable Talent
definition.description: By 11th level, you have refined your chosen skills until they approach perfection. Whenever you make an ability check that lets you add your proficiency bonus, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.
definition.snippet: Whenever you make an ability check that lets you add your proficiency bonus, you can treat a d20 roll of 9 or lower as a 10.

definition.name: Blindsense
definition.description: Starting at 14th level, if you are able to hear, you are aware of the location of any hidden or invisible creature within 10 feet of you.
definition.snippet: If you are able to hear, you are aware of the location of any hidden or invisible creature within 10 ft. of you.

definition.name: Slippery Mind
definition.description: By 15th level, you have acquired greater mental strength. You gain proficiency in Wisdom saving throws.
definition.snippet: You gain proficiency in Wisdom saving throws.

definition.name: Elusive
definition.description: Beginning at 18th level, you are so evasive that attackers rarely gain the upper hand against you. No attack roll has advantage against you while you aren’t incapacitated.
definition.snippet: No attack roll has advantage against you while you aren’t incapacitated.

definition.name: Stroke of Luck
definition.description:
At 20th level, you have an uncanny knack for succeeding when you need to. If your attack misses a target within range, you can turn the miss into a hit. Alternatively, if you fail an ability check, you can treat the d20 roll as a 20.

Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a short or long rest.
definition.snippet: Once per short rest, if your attack misses a target within range, you can turn the miss into a hit. Alternatively, if you fail an ability check, you can treat the d20 roll as a 20.

definition.name: Proficiencies
definition.description:
Armor: Light armor
Weapons: Simple weapons, hand crossbows, longswords, rapiers, shortswords
Tools: Thieves’ tools
Saving Throws: Dexterity, Intelligence
Skills: Choose four from Acrobatics, Athletics, Deception, Insight, Intimidation, Investigation, Perception, Performance, Persuasion, Sleight of Hand, and Stealth

Armor: Light armor
Tools: Thieves’ tools
Skills: Choose one from Acrobatics, Athletics, Deception, Insight, Intimidation, Investigation, Perception, Performance, Persuasion, Sleight of Hand, and Stealth

definition.name: Expertise
definition.description: At 6th level, choose two more of your skill proficiencies, or one more of your skill proficiencies and your proficiency with thieves’ tools. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.
definition.snippet: Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses any of the chosen proficiencies.

definition.name: Hit Points
definition.description:
Hit Dice: 1d8 per rogue level
Hit Points at 1st Level: 8 + your Constitution modifier
Hit Points at Higher Levels: 1d8 (or 5) + your Constitution modifier per rogue level after 1st

definition.name: Ability Score Improvement
definition.description:
When you reach 10th level, and again at 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Using the optional feats rule, you can forgo taking this feature to take a feat of your choice instead.

race.name: Mask of the Wild
race.description: You can attempt to [action]hide[/action] even when you are only lightly obscured by foliage, heavy rain, falling snow, mist, and other natural phenomena.
race.snippet: You can attempt to hide even when you are only lightly obscured.

class.name: Sneak Attack
class.description:
Beginning at 1st level, you know how to strike subtly and exploit a foe’s distraction. Once per turn, you can deal an extra 1d6 damage to one creature you hit with an attack if you have advantage on the attack roll. The attack must use a finesse or a ranged weapon.

You don’t need advantage on the attack roll if another enemy of the target is within 5 feet of it, that enemy isn’t [condition]incapacitated[/condition], and you don’t have disadvantage on the attack roll.

The amount of the extra damage increases as you gain levels in this class, as shown in the Sneak Attack column of the Rogue table.
class.snippet: Once per turn, you can deal an extra {{scalevalue}} damage to one creature you hit with an attack with a finesse or ranged weapon if you have advantage on the attack roll. You don’t need advantage on the attack roll if another enemy of the target is within 5 ft. of it, that enemy isn’t incapacitated, and you don’t have disadvantage on the attack roll.

customItems.name: Duergar Puzzle Box
customItems.description:
Carved from a chunk of Stygian obsidian and metal alloys, the box's cold, dark exterior is etched with intricate geometric patterns that twist and turn, creating a labyrinthine network of lines. Small and almost imperceptible, silver etchings shimmer mysteriously under the faintest light, revealing an intricate map of shifting pathways. The stark contrast between the deep black obsidian and the vibrant etchings creates a mesmerizing tableau, like a starlit night sky as seen through a kaleidoscope.

The box's precise construction is visible in its series of interlocking panels and rotating sections, each moving with an eerie smoothness that belies the solidity of the obsidian. Despite its delicate complexity, the puzzle box is deceptively robust, showing no signs of wear or damage despite the trials of time.

It's impossible to distinguish any obvious opening or lock. Instead, the enigma of the box unfolds as an organic whole, a tantalizing interplay of form and function. The artifact is as silent as a tomb, devoid of any rattling or hint of what it might contain.
